name: Aaron Sumner
body:
## Experience

#### Director of Technology for Research and Development/Project Manager (2005-present)

*University of Kansas Center for Research on Learning, Lawrence KS*

Design and implement web software for education research projects using Ruby on Rails, MySQL, RSpec, jQuery, Sass, and Haml. Administer multiple Linux and Mac OS X web and database servers. Managed a team of programmers and educational technologists. Serve as technology expert during grant proposal writing activities. Represent CRL at national and regional education conferences.

#### Senior Computing Specialist (2002-2005)

*University of Washington Department of Psychology, Seattle WA*

Developed the departmental website using PHP, MySQL, CSS, and HTML. Administered Linux and Mac OS X web and database servers. Managed all classroom technology for the department, including four computer labs. Nominated for UW Employee of the Year, 2005.

#### Technology Coordinator (2000-2002)

*University of Kansas Center for Research on Learning, Lawrence KS*

Developed web-based publishing systems and data tracking tools using PHP, MySQL, CSS, and HTML. Created online-ready learning content using Flash and JavaScript. Administered Linux servers, networks, and Macintosh and Windows-based labs. Represented CRL at national education conferences.

#### Web Developer (1999-2000)

*University of Kansas Medical Center, Kansas City KS*

Created web software for public, campus, and departmental purposes using Perl, VBScript, SQL, HTML, and Java. Developed a web-based bridge to the hospitalâ€™s directory assistance software and tools for tracking DMCA complaints. Assisted in the administration of Unix and NT servers.

#### Network Communications Coordinator (1996-1999)

*University of Kansas Department of Special Education, Lawrence KS*

Designed and developed web software and sites using Perl, SQL, and HTML. Wrote early web-based project management, content management, and surveying tools. Managed Unix-based servers, networks, and Macintosh-based labs.
